BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as the precipitation becomes more intense.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Up to 2000 m and above rain will fall. New snow at intermediate altitudes.

As the precipitation becomes more intense dry and moist avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large in some cases, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls and at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation in particular. In the typical avalanche paths here the avalanches can in some cases reach the bare valleys.
As a consequence of the rain individual ground avalanches are possible.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular adjacent to ridgelines can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2300 m. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and the danger is greater.
During the day: In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation above approximately 2500 m in some localities danger level 4 (high) will be reached.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
70 to 80 cm of snow, but less in some localities, will fall in the next few hours above approximately 2300 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the new snow.
The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
The weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack also at intermediate and high altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of new snow and wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the late morning. The avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach very large size. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,. Up to 2200 m rain will fall from late morning over a wide area. As the moisture increases large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected, in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. The conditions are critical for backcountry touring and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2500 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the snow.
The wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Intensive rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to rapid moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the late morning. The avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach very large size. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,. Up to 2200 m rain will fall from late morning over a wide area. As the moisture increases large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected, in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. The conditions are critical for backcountry touring and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2500 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the snow.
The wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Intensive rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to rapid moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the late morning. The avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach large size. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,. Up to 2000 m rain will fall from late morning. As the moisture increases medium-sized and large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected, especially at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. Ski touring and snowshoe hiking call for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2500 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: On Thursday as a consequence of the precipitation there will be a gradual increase in the danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as the precipitation becomes more intense.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Up to 2000 m and above rain will fall. New snow at intermediate altitudes.
As the precipitation becomes more intense dry and moist avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large in isolated cases, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls and at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation in particular, in particular, along the border with Switzerland.
As a consequence of the rain individual ground avalanches are possible.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular adjacent to ridgelines can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2300 m. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and the danger is greater.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall in the next few hours above approximately 2300 m, especially, along the border with Switzerland. The southeasterly wind will transport the new snow.
The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
The weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack also at intermediate and high altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of new snow and wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation the size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the late morning. In particular on very steep slopes the avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach quite a large size. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Above approximately 2500 m in some localities danger level 4 (high) will be reached. Up to 2100 m rain will fall from late morning. As the moisture increases medium-sized and large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected, especially at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. Ski touring and snowshoe hiking call for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2500 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Intensive rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation the size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the late morning. In particular on very steep slopes the avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach quite a large size. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Above approximately 2500 m in some localities danger level 4 (high) will be reached. Up to 2100 m rain will fall from late morning. As the moisture increases medium-sized and large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected, especially at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. Ski touring and snowshoe hiking call for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2500 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Intensive rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger. Moist and wet avalanches are to be expected already in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Up to 2100 m rain will fall from late morning. As the moisture increases medium-sized and large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected, especially at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. As a consequence of the precipitation the size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the late morning. In particular on very steep slopes the avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach quite a large size. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, but less in some localities, will fall above approximately 2500 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Intensive rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will increase quickly in the early morning. More small to medium-sized wet avalanches are possible. This applies in all aspects below approximately 2800 m, as well as on extremely steep sunny slopes in high Alpine regions.
In very isolated cases avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach a dangerous size.

In addition still more very occasional gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

High Alpine regions: The fresh and older wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering. Very isolated avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the temporarily overcast night and will soften quickly. The high temperatures from the early morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack in all aspects below approximately 2800 m, this also applies on sunny slopes in high Alpine regions.

High Alpine regions: In some localities up to 15 cm of snow will fall. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form in particular in the vicinity of peaks. The no longer entirely fresh wind slabs of the last few days are now only very rarely prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will increase quickly in the early morning. More small to medium-sized wet avalanches are possible. This applies in all aspects below approximately 2800 m, as well as on extremely steep sunny slopes at elevated altitudes.
In very isolated cases avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach a dangerous size.

In addition still more very occasional gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the temporarily overcast night. The high temperatures from the early morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack in all aspects below approximately 2800 m, this also applies on sunny slopes at elevated altitudes.

At low and intermediate altitudes from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes deep wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Some fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Some fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. As a consequence of the rain small and medium-sized natural wet avalanches are possible in all altitude zones.
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches in the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the precipitation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually especially on extremely steep sunny slopes. Mostly these are small. This also applies in isolated cases on shady slopes below approximately 2800 m.

In addition further gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes.
The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall in some regions. This applies above approximately 2000 m. The danger of dry and wet avalanches will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation individual moist and wet avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. The avalanches can occur naturally as well. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in extremely steep terrain at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of rain up to approximately 2200 m an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop. These conditions will cause a weakening of the near-surface layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From the early morning as a consequence of warming there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. Backcountry tours should be started and concluded very early.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects wet loose snow avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Gliding avalanches can also occur. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can still in isolated cases be released by small loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions will give rise to moistening of the snowpack.
Wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. This applies in particular on shady slopes.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The danger of wet avalanches will already increase in the late morning. Especially on extremely steep slopes individual mostly small wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the temporarily overcast night and will soften quickly. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

At low and intermediate altitudes from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in danger of wet avalanches in the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually. This applies in all aspects. Mostly the avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning.

Below approximately 1800 m no snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 2000 m snow will fall. The danger of moist and wet snow slides will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation individual moist and wet avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. The avalanches can occur naturally as well. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in extremely steep terrain at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. The rain will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack. The meteorological conditions will bring about a weakening of the snowpack in particular on very steep slopes.
